p: Attraction towards human odor of each species was estimated as a percentage of trapped females that were caught in the trap with human odor. This index of attraction varies from 0% (full attraction to CO 2 without human odor) to 100% (full attraction to CO 2 with human odor), with 50% indicating a neutral behavior (no effect of the human odor). To rule out any bias in the intrinsic attractiveness of the traps, we also performed control CO 2 only vs. CO 2 only experiments for each species. In the control experiments, 51% (95% CI: 36.8–65.2) of Ae. aegypti females and 56.2% (95% CI: 28.9–83.6) of Ae. malayensis females chose one trap over the other. For both species, the percentage of mosquitoes in each trap did not significantly differ from 50%, which confirmed the lack of bias between the traps. As expected, 87.5% (95% CI: 81.9–93.1) of trapped Ae. aegypti females chose the trap with human odor (Fig. 3B), indicating significant attraction to human odor. In contrast, 33.3% (95% CI: 14.3–52.3) of trapped Ae. malayensis chose the trap with human odor (Fig. 3B), and this percentage was not statistically different from 50% indicating a lack of response to human odor. Accordingly, relative attraction towards human odor was significantly lower for Ae. malayensis than for Ae. aegypti ( p < 0.0001; Fig. 3B). Overall, these experiments revealed that Ae. malayensis was not attracted to human odor (i.e., it did not specifically choose the trap containing the human odor), but was activated by human odor (i.e., it initiated flight and host-seeking behavior) as more females responded to the combination of CO 2 and human odor than to CO 2 alone.
